comments.commentBody: About Time!

The Bush tax cuts have been in effect for almost a decade  - so my question is given the lowest tax rates in decades how many new jobs have been created in the last ten years by the so-called "job creators" the GOP leadership is constantly talking about?  Oh ... I thought so!  Time for class warfare in the streets!

"Truth crushed to the earth shall rise again" Willam Cullen Bryant. The truth defined as the lower and middle class being crushed for so long by the upper class since the Bush tax cuts have been in effect. The truth is rising ya'll. Stay Tuned.

Taxes are collected (by force) to enable government to spend it in the "public interest". Since 72% of our fellow citizens think the country is headed in the wrong direction, it would seem that Obama's new and original ideas re tax and spend contradict what public perception is, and is rather destined to be spent to perpetuate the wrong direction.

More smoke and mirrors of debt reduction, too. Take out all the double counting and doublespeak and the bottom line comes out to be more like $1.5 trillion over ten years. That assumes also that bureaucrats can really turn themselves in by finding $500 billion in waste and fraud.

Jay in the Last House on the Left Coast.... looks like you may have to split the sheets and co-habit, bud. That is on the approved list of the progressives.

Doesn't matter how much one earns annually but allowing $one-million
for each member of Ono's family as a year's personal enjoyment is too much imbalancing where e.g. another entire hard-working middle class family of a more intelligent guy can see in own pocket not even one hundred thousand annually! This is a disease just like atomic imbalance in a cancerous human body cell and the constant acts of trying to balance everything in our life is the meaning in our being alive. I like when someone suggests "praying to religion-less Creator" and it's mysteriously effective!
I don't like to watch unnecessarily worried mental states of people. Men-made problems are solvable by collective human intelligence free of humanly selfishness! In religion-less God's power we need to trust that acts constructive or destructively through its creations for creations.

Of course the 50% reality and 50% Cosmic drama of 9/11 involved some then real criminals who at the moment of impact became just chemicals and atomic particles that forms existence of all of the creations based on only one balancing '50% rule'. A faceless group took advantage of that event only for power and making money.
We should identify the invisible guys but with an honest attitude of forgiveness toward shortcomings of mankind with an expectation since they are human they have the mental ability to understand our generosity and won't bite us back like poisonous snakes we intentionally set free! Kill or be killed is a ugly part of cosmic rules that is applicable to wilderness or by uncivilized state of human mind(s).

I am surprised to watch the things, I co-incidentally wrote about long ago, are unfolding to become reality now.

Here is a excerpt from a document I started writing years ago for my application to the Upper Canadian Judicial system of which I really feel so proud!

...............................Today I have felt like, you OLRB have thrown at me a loaded garbage bag from your aloft pos

Enough with "common ground."  With the Tea Party riding high, there is no longer a "common ground" in American politics.  Why should Obama endlessly pursue the failed tactic of trying to compromise with zealots?  Despite the best efforts of the Republican-Fat Cat noise machine, most Americans believe the rich should pay their fair share of taxes.  Obama has finally called the Republican-Tea Party's bluff.  A majority of Americans support him.  If the Tea Party stymies this move, he ends up with a viable reelection issue provided he and the Democrats use it to regain a majority in the House and widen their majority in the Senate.  Otherwise, things will get even worse--and the Republicans' long-term plan to evict grandpa and starve grandma will succeed.  Class war?  That's what the Republicans and their corporate funders have been conducting all along, warring against working people and the poor.  These people desperately need a champion. Obama, who has so often betrayed his supporters for the sake of Wall Street's profits, may belatedly be that champion.

James Rickover, comment 238
"What would Mr Dawkins say to the thousands of "born again" Christians that claim to have had a personal experience with God?"
Easy - they didn't. They thought they did, like a schizophrenic really hears voices. But, like the schizophrenic, there was no God or gods, just like there are no disembodied voices.
The born-agains just had a personal experience with chemicals in their bodies that caused them to think what they thought they did. Throw in the cultural background (there are very few stories of Bible Belters suddenly getting all "personal" with Vishnu or Ganesh...) and there's your answer :-)

comments.userLocation: Unspecified Location in the Upper Midwest
comments.commentBody:
Failure has recently become a big part of our child rearing curriculum. Sometime after turning 13, our perfect daughter was replaced by a clone who, among other things, refused to do homework. After two quarters worth of kitchen table fights, we gave up and let her actions lead to their natural end. Two hard-earned "D" grades later -- one in a subject I teach at a local university -- our former high honor student learned a lesson.

It's not an easy lesson for either parent or child; certainly my husband and I were as embarassed as our daughter when grades were released. And I can't say that we would have allowed her the freedom to fail if she were at the point where the grades would have shown up on a college application, but it did work and she is now a more responsible and reasonable young teenager. A little failure -- in this case a spectacular failure -- sometimes works.

Dawkins doesn't bash; he reasons, applying science. Gets to the Truth:
THE UNIVERSE IS ATHEIST. IT DOESN'T BELIEVE IN ME.

It's good that somebody is spending the time to point out the folly in building elaborate institutions dedicated to a being whose existence has merit because it has yet to be disproved by the tools of science.

#241 Richard Haymes says: "...how can anyone understand the notion of god without ever having had a religious(spiritual) experience?"

No offense, Richard, but I had them too, before I realized they were illusions.

"...testimonies of such vital experiences are as old as history itself. "

so is psychopathology.

"...we are not just rational creatures"

That's for sure!

"we are also worshipful creatures. perhaps i might try writing a hymn to science and reason and see if it "addresses my essential loneliness and fear"

How about open-minded Humanism to address your loneliness and fear? We Humanists live fulfilled and happy lives with purpose and without sacrificing our reason.

Metaphysics, or the idea that the "universe" is somehow the totality of all that is, in a consciousness that knows itself through its own existence, includes evolution and science without issue. Science, unfortunately, does not include metaphysics. That says all one needs to know.

God and religion, of course, are concepts made up by humans to describe the unknown. "My god's better than your god" is a consequence of that. What trouble has come from that game!

# 10 Spalding ... I may screw up the 10 comments suggestion. S0 let's say 10 less mine lol.

As you were.
Still letting the shill/troll/cherrypicker wmar spew disinformation all over your comments threads, Andy?  Why?

There's nothing new here. As the torrent of denier posts to your blog indicate,  there is a core audience dedicated to creating a virtual reality even if that effort accelerates global warming and associated extreme weather events.

Was Breitbart's effort as bad as the New York Times blatant, error-filled attack on Darrell Issa? It's not like this is Walter Duranty covering up for the Soviet Union's crimes against humanity. Jeesh.

Andrew Breitbart is my hero and I hope he is the press secretary for the next President (cuz you just know the Republican will win!)
Andy, I believe Ike Solem was referring to lack of coverage in the NYT about current flooding in Pakistan. You linked to a 2010 piece.

I watched the video of Jasper Kirkby explaining the premise of the CERN cloud experiment with some interest. I could see why it might appeal to the Nascar/ Monster truck crowd of which Breibart seems to be a member. After all, It’s men playing with big toys as opposed to scientists spending months taking samples or doing surveys in the field or pouring over data in the lab. What I found most interesting is not what the results of the experiments were telling them, but just how little they really knew at this point.

One thing that caught my attention was the fact that in order for the cosmic rays to actually induce cloud condensing nuclei they first had to interact with some as yet unidentified trace gas. It’s an amusing prospect to consider but it would be quite ironic if that gas was found to be something produced in part by anthropogenic processes. If that was then affecting the climate in some adverse way, would climate skeptics be so willing to accept the results of the study. One can only wonder.

re wmar #4, 7, 9 13- I appreciate your efforts to post these examples. I decided this would be a 'shooting fish in a barrel' exercise.

So instead, here is a short excerpt of the extensive list of items that are claimed to be the result of global warming, maintained by John Brignell at Numberwatch. Hopefully some journalism professor may someday create a class assignment to have the students investigate the veracity of these claims...

"...hibernation affected, hibernation ends too soon, hibernation ends too late, homeless 50 million, hornets, human development faces unprecedented reversal, human fertility reduced, human health risk, human race oblivion, human rights violations, hurricanes, hurricane reduction, hurricanes fewer, hurricanes more intense, hurricanes not, hydropower problems, hyperthermia deaths, hypothermia deaths, ice age, ice sheet growth, ice sheet shrinkage, icebergs, icesheet tipping point, illegal immigration, illness and death, inclement weather, India drowning, infrastructure failure (Canada), indigestion,..."

Inspirational quote on climate change-
"I think the objectivity standard that U.S. newspapers apply has probably outlived its usefulness on this particular issue,"
Mark Neuzil, professor, University of St. Thomas, July 2011
For a follower of World Nuclear News and Brave New Climate, the abstracts of articles in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists were entirely predictable.
The Nature news article is good.

Now we quit eat sharks fin soup is for humanisty and protect endangrous species. As human want to eat sharks fin soup, they killed so many sharks, even they only cut the sharks fin and back them into ocean, still they died in the ocean. Maybe now we quit eat sharks and whales fin soup, can show our human evoluate a little.

Dr. Judy Curry, who is something of an expert on this had a posting on this on her blog about 10 days ago. http://judithcurry.com/2011/09/08/extreme-measures/#more-4851 She described the ACE project as "scientifically unsound" and recommended that there are others more qualified to do this analysis. Another extreme climate expert (hurricanes), Chris Landsea is not mentioned but Trenberth was. You may recall that Trenberth caused Landsea to resign from the IPCC for misrepresenting his work on hurricanes. I also did not see a quote or mention from Roger Pielke Jr. who is also an expert on extreme events. No, you just have the usual cast of characters, who have a conclusion that is in desperate need of support so they've created a panel of expert witnesses that can be relied upon to support prosecution of greenhouse gases.
Much ado about...

In somethng like this one it's more fun to use a yo-yo or build a spool and try it out as a real experiment.  It might help to have the spool discs roll in grooves in a piece of wood so that if the pull point is not exactly in the midplane of the spool, the spool axis won't skew during motion.  In the case of a yo-yo I'd wrap a broad rubber band around the rim of each half to encourage friction.
